articles.headline: Is the Bear Market Over? It Depends.
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 ended the day nearly 20 percent above its low last year, within a hair of a milestone for some market watchers. But assessing a bona fide bull market is not so simple.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 ended the day nearly 20 percent above its low last year, within a hair of a milestone for some market watchers. But assessing a bona fide bull market is not so simple.
articles.lead_paragraph: The S&P 500, the index obsessed over by investors, executives and government officials, on Monday came close to finishing 20 percent above its lowest level of 2022, a gain that some on Wall Street see as the start of a bull market and a new phase of investing exuberance.

articles.headline: Robert Hanssen, F.B.I. Agent Exposed as Spy for Moscow, Dies at 79
articles.snippet: Mr. Hanssen was sentenced to life in prison in 2002, bringing to a close one of the most lurid and damaging espionage cases in American history.
articles.abstract: Mr. Hanssen was sentenced to life in prison in 2002, bringing to a close one of the most lurid and damaging espionage cases in American history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert P. Hanssen, a former F.B.I. agent who spied for Moscow off and on for more than two decades during and after the Cold War in one of the most damaging espionage cases in American history, was discovered dead in his prison cell in Colorado on Monday, federal authorities announced. He was 79.

articles.headline: Chris Licht of CNN Faces a Crisis. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: Mr. Licht, the network’s chief executive, said on an internal call on Monday that he would “fight like hell” to win back the trust of the network.
articles.abstract: Mr. Licht, the network’s chief executive, said on an internal call on Monday that he would “fight like hell” to win back the trust of the network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ratings have plummeted. Profits have shrunk. A top star has been pushed out.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: As Ukrainian Attacks Surge, U.S. Officials See Signs of Counteroffensive
articles.snippet: Kyiv has not formally announced the start of operations. But on Tuesday, Ukraine said the Russians had blown up a dam on the Dnipro River, potentially imperiling residents and the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.
articles.abstract: Kyiv has not formally announced the start of operations. But on Tuesday, Ukraine said the Russians had blown up a dam on the Dnipro River, potentially imperiling residents and the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have stepped up artillery strikes and ground assaults in a flurry of military activity that American officials suggested on Monday could signal that Kyiv’s long-planned counteroffensive against Russia had begun.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Biden Administration Shrugs Off Ukraine’s Attacks in Russia
articles.snippet: For months, U.S. officials said cross-border operations risked a dangerous escalation. But those fears have ebbed.
articles.abstract: For months, U.S. officials said cross-border operations risked a dangerous escalation. But those fears have ebbed.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the first year of Russia’s war in Ukraine, the Biden administration fretted constantly that if Kyiv hit back inside Russian borders, President Vladimir V. Putin would retaliate against not only Ukraine, but also possibly NATO and the West.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: A Reporter Investigated Sexual Misconduct. Then the Attacks Began.
articles.snippet: After publishing an exposé, journalists in New Hampshire faced broken windows, vulgar graffiti and a legal brawl, with important First Amendment implications.
articles.abstract: After publishing an exposé, journalists in New Hampshire faced broken windows, vulgar graffiti and a legal brawl, with important First Amendment implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: One drizzly Saturday in May last year, a slender man in a blue raincoat approached a house in the Boston suburb of Melrose. It was just before 6 a.m., and no one was around. The man took out a can of red spray paint and scrawled “JUST THE BEGINNING!” on the side of the white house. Then he hurled a brick through a large window and sprinted away.

articles.headline: Coinbase Accused of Breaking Market Rules as Crypto Crackdown Widens
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. said the cryptocurrency platform allowed users to trade unregistered securities, a day after it accused the crypto platform Binance of mishandling funds.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. said the cryptocurrency platform allowed users to trade unregistered securities, a day after it accused the crypto platform Binance of mishandling funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an intensifying effort to end what the authorities see as the era of lawlessness in the cryptocurrency market, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday sued Coinbase, the largest crypto trading platform in the United States, claiming that the company broke the law by not registering as a broker.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Ephrat Livni and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: A First Try of Apple’s $3,500 Vision Pro Headset
articles.snippet: I briefly got my hands on Apple’s new high-tech goggles, which impressed and creeped me out and raised a question: Why do we need these?
articles.abstract: I briefly got my hands on Apple’s new high-tech goggles, which impressed and creeped me out and raised a question: Why do we need these?
articles.lead_paragraph: I got a sneak peek into Apple’s vision for the future of computing on Monday. For about half an hour, I wore the $3,500 Vision Pro, the company’s first high-tech goggles, which will be released next year.
